query: To protect newly planted trees from herbivores, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of fencing compared to using individual tree guards or shelters?
relevant_summary:
One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that using light-coloured, but not dark-coloured, plastic tree shelters increased the survival rate of planted tree seedlings (1268). A replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 months, but not after 44 months (1268). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that plastic guards increased the height and diameter growth rates of planted baldcypress seedlings over one growing season (3330).

When it comes to fencing, one replicated, paired, controlled study in Australia reported that planted swamp gum seedlings had a much higher survival rate over one year in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots (3330). However, two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased the survival of planted tree seedlings, but sometimes had no clear or significant effect, depending on factors such as the season of planting, seedling elevation, and site (3330). One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years (3330). The same study did find that the fenced plots contained taller tree seedlings after three years (3330). In contrast, a different replicated, paired, controlled study in the USA found that the average height of white cedar saplings increased by a similar amount between two and five years after planting in plots that were fenced to exclude deer and plots that were left unfenced (3330). Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in Canada and Israel reported that protecting emergent herbs with silt screens or herbivore fencing increased survival rates over 12–18 months after planting (3328). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of using fences or barriers to protect planted peatland vegetation (1839).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effectiveness of fencing compared to individual tree guards for protecting newly planted trees from herbivores"}
{"query_string":"effectiveness of individual tree guards or shelters for protecting newly planted trees from herbivores"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3328",
  "action_title": "Use fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with non-woody plants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Four studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with emergent, non-woody plants. There was one study in each of Canada, the Netherlands, Israel and the USA.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that amongst planted/sown lakeshores, those protected with fences or wave breaks contained different wetland plant communities, after 1–6 years, than those without fences or wave breaks.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Individual species abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study at the edge of a freshwater lake in the Netherlands found that amongst plots planted with lakeshore bulrush Scirpus lacustris, those from which wildfowl had been excluded contained a greater density and biomass of lakeshore bulrush, after 1–2 years, than those that remained open to wildfowl.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE
 
OTHER

Survival (2 studies): Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in Canada and Israel reported that protecting emergent herbs, with silt screens or herbivore fencing, increased survival rates over 12–18 months after planting."
}

{
  "action_id": "3330",
  "action_title": "Use fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, those also fenced to exclude deer contained taller tree seedlings, after three years, than those left unfenced. One replicated, paired, controlled study in created freshwater wetlands in the USA found that the average height of white cedar Thuja occidentalis saplings typically increased by a similar amount, between two and five years after planting, in plots fenced to exclude deer and plots left unfenced.

OTHER

Survival (3 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in floodplain swamps in Australia reported that planted swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora seedlings had a much higher survival rate, over one year, in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings but sometimes had no clear or significant effect. This depended on factors such as the season of planting, seedling elevation, and site.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in a nutria-invaded wetland in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings grew more, over one growing season, when protected than when left unprotected. Plastic guards increased height and diameter growth rates. Sticky, insect-repellent oil increased the growth rate for height, but not diameter."
}

query: What are the documented effects of removing competing understory vegetation on planted trees and overall forest biodiversity?
relevant_summary: Five studies in Canada, the USA, France, Panama, and Sweden found no effect of controlling understory vegetation on the emergence, survival, growth rate or frost damage of planted seedlings (1256). However, one found that removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass (1256). Another replicated, controlled study in Canada found that the removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased the growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings (1256). One randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species, but not abundance, were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without (781). Three studies in the USA, two of which were randomized, replicated, and controlled, found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (778). One replicated, site comparison study in Canada found that following logging, American toad abundance was similar and wood frogs were lower in stands with herbicide treatment and planting compared to stands left to regenerate naturally (778).

query: In degraded forest areas, what interventions are available to improve soil conditions and enhance tree growth?
relevant_summary: In degraded forest areas, one of two randomized, replicated, controlled studies in Australia found that different soil enhancers had mixed effects on tree seedling survival and height, but no effect on tree seedling health (1153). The other study found that combinations of soil enhancers did not increase seedling survival, height, diameter or health (1153). Two replicated, controlled studies from Canada and Finland found that disturbance of the forest floor decreased understory vegetation cover (1252). Additionally, six of eight studies in the USA, Finland, Brazil, Australia and Switzerland found that applying fertilizer increased total plant cover, understory plant biomass, size of young trees, and cover of artificially seeded plant species (1248). However, five of these studies found no effect of applying fertilizer on plant biomass, plant cover, seedling abundance, tree growth and tree seedling diversity (1248).

query: What is the state of the evidence regarding the effectiveness of managing public access and tourism to mitigate human disturbance in forests?
relevant_summary: Six studies from across the world found that following the implementation of access restrictions or the placement of signs near nesting areas, there were increased numbers of breeders, higher reproductive success, or lower levels of disturbance in waders and terns [309]. Additionally, a study in the USA reported the successful relocation of a black-crowned night heron colony to an area with no public access [309]. However, one study in Europe and another in Antarctica found no effect of access restrictions on the reproductive success of eagles or penguins, respectively [309]. In the context of eco-tourism, one study in the USA found that 32% of survey respondents would have sought out a nesting turtle on their own if they had not been able to join a supervised turtle watch [3680]. Another study in St Kitts and Nevis revealed that individuals who participated in a leatherback turtle tour reported that they would be more mindful of how their actions on the beach could affect sea turtles [3680]. There was no evidence found regarding the effects of prohibiting food consumption in natural areas where primates could see people on primate populations [1508].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"managing public access and tourism to mitigate human disturbance in forests"}

query: How does the effectiveness of managing livestock grazing to protect forests vary across different geographical locations mentioned in the evidence?
relevant_summary: The evidence documents do not contain information on the effectiveness of managing livestock grazing to protect forests. One study in France found that one reptile species was more abundant in areas grazed by sheep than in areas managed by burning [3711]. A study in the USA found that after grazing cattle to restore bog turtle habitat, along with providing artificial nest covers, more bog turtle eggs were laid and hatching success was higher than before [3711]. The nests of bog turtles were laid only in areas that had been grazed in the current or previous growing season [3711]. No studies were found that evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of allowing different types of livestock to graze freshwater swamps or freshwater marshes [2980, 2978].

query: What management techniques involving tree removal can be used to increase forest structural diversity and what are their effects?
relevant_summary: Shelterwood harvesting, when used instead of clearcutting, can lead to higher plant diversity, a greater density of tree species, and reduced grass cover [1214]. It has been found to increase the abundance, species richness, and diversity of understory plants, along with improving the growth and survival rate of young trees. However, one study noted a decrease in plant species richness and abundance, and another found no impact on tree abundance [1223]. Additionally, shelterwood harvesting's effects on reptile species richness and abundance were mixed when compared to areas with no management. In one instance, it resulted in a lower abundance of juvenile eastern box turtles compared to clearcut areas [3636]. One study also indicated that this method had no effect on red oak acorn production [1223].

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting had mixed effects on reptile species richness compared to areas with no management.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized study in the USA found that areas with shelterwood harvesting had a lower abundance of juvenile eastern box turtles than clearcut areas. One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting had mixed effects on reptile abundance compared to areas with no management.

query: What are the documented effects of thinning trees on the various components of a forest ecosystem, including mature trees, young trees, and understory plants?
relevant_summary:
Eleven of 12 studies found that thinning trees in forests decreased the density and cover of mature trees [1209]. Five of six studies found that thinning increased the size of mature trees [1209]. One study found that thinning decreased tree species richness and diversity [1209]. The effect of thinning on tree mortality caused by bark beetles is varied; one study found that thinning reduced the number of conifers killed by beetles, while two other studies found no effect [1209].

For young trees, six of 12 studies found that thinning increased their density, while one study found a decrease, and five studies found no effect or mixed effects [1210]. One study found that thinning increased the growth rate of young trees [1210].

Regarding understory plants, 17 of 25 studies found that thinning increased their density and cover, while seven studies found no effect or mixed effects, and one study found a decrease in the abundance of herbaceous species [1211]. Thirteen of 19 studies found that thinning increased the species richness and diversity of understory plants, while seven studies found no effect [1211].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of thinning trees on a forest ecosystem"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "1209",
  "action_title": "Thin trees within forests: effects on mature trees",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven of 12 studies (including two replicated, randomized, controlled studies) in Brazil, Canada, and the USA found that thinning trees in forests decreased the density and cover of trees. One study found no effect of thinning on tree density.
Five of six studies (including one replicated, controlled, before-and-after study) in Australia, Sweden and the USA found that thinning trees in forests increased tree size. One found mixed effects of thinning on tree size.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that thinning trees in forests decreased tree species richness and diversity.
One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that thinning reduced the number of conifers killed by beetles. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found no effect of thinning on bark-beetle caused tree mortality."
}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "2650",
  "action_title": "Thin trees within forest",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twelve studies evaluated the effects on mammals of thinning trees within forests. Six studies were in Canada and six were in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Species richness (2 studies): A replicated, site comparison study the USA found that in thinned tree forest stands, there was similar mammal species richness compared to in unthinned stands. A replicated, controlled study  in Canada found that thinning of regenerating lodgepole pine did not increase small mammal species richness 12–14 years later.

POPULATION RESPONSE (8 STUDIES)

Abundance (8 studies): Three of eight replicated, controlled and replicated, site comparison studies, in the USA and Canada, found that thinning trees within forests lead to higher numbers of small mammals. Two studies showed increases for some, but not all, small mammal species with a further study showing an increase for one of two squirrel species in response to at least some forest thinning treatments. The other two studies showed no increases in abundances of small mammals or northern flying squirrels between 12 and 14 years after thinning.

BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): Three of four controlled and comparison studies (three also replicated, one randomized) in Canada found that thinning trees within forests did not lead to greater use of areas by mule deer, moose or snowshoe hares. The other study found that a thinned area was used more by white-tailed deer than was unthinned forest."
}

{
  "action_id": "3627",
  "action_title": "Thin trees within forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of thinning trees within forests on reptile populations. Three studies were in the USA and one was in each of Brazil, Spain and Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): Two replicated, controlled studies (including one randomized study) in the USA and Spain found that areas of thinned forest had similar reptile species richness compared to areas with no thinning. One study also found that thinned areas had lower species richness than areas of open habitat. One replicated, controlled study in Australia found that areas of forest thinned 8–20 years previously had higher diversity of reptiles than areas thinned less than eight or more than 20 years previously, or than areas with no thinning.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): Two of four replicated, controlled studies (including two randomized studies) in Brazil, the USA, and Spain found that areas of thinned forest had a similar abundance of reptiles compared to areas with no thinning. One study found mixed effects of thinning trees on the abundance of three lizard species. The other study found that areas of thinned forest had a higher abundance of reptiles than areas with no thinning. That study also found that areas with the most thinning had a similar abundance of reptiles compared to areas of open habitat. One replicated, controlled study in Australia found that areas of forest thinned 8–20 years previously had a higher abundance of reptiles than areas thinned at other times or areas with no thinning. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that areas of thinned forest had a higher abundance of snakes than clearcut forest.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of thinning trees on understory plants"}

query: To avoid the impacts of clearcutting in European and North American forests, what are the documented effects of alternative harvesting methods like shelterwood or partial retention harvesting?
relevant_summary:
Shelterwood harvesting has been found to have varying effects. Six out of seven studies in Australia, Iran, Nepal, and the USA showed that shelterwood harvesting increased the abundance, species richness, and diversity of understory plants, along with the growth and survival rate of young trees [1223]. However, one study found a decrease in plant species richness and abundance, and another found no effect on tree abundance [1223]. In terms of wildlife, two studies in the USA on reptile populations found that shelterwood harvesting had mixed effects on reptile species richness and abundance compared to areas with no management [3636]. One study in the USA found that areas with shelterwood harvesting had a lower abundance of juvenile eastern box turtles than clearcut areas [3636]. When compared to clearcutting, three studies in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance [851]. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America indicated that partial harvest, including shelterwood harvesting, led to smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting [851].

Partial retention harvesting has also been studied as an alternative to clearcutting. Three studies in Canada found that using partial retention harvesting instead of clearcutting decreased the density of young trees [1215].

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized study in the USA found that areas with shelterwood harvesting had a lower abundance of juvenile eastern box turtles than clearcut areas. One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that shelterwood harvesting had mixed effects on reptile abundance compared to areas with no management.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

query: What is the state of the evidence regarding different methods for restoring forests by adding or encouraging biological material like seeds, plants, or beneficial organisms?
relevant_summary: Thirteen of fifteen studies found that bird communities in restored forests were similar to those in original forests, that species returned to restored sites, that species recovered significantly better than at unrestored sites, that species richness, diversity, or abundances increased over time, or that restoration techniques themselves improved over time (360). Nine of the studies found that some species did not return to restored sites or were less common than in original forests, and one study found that overall territory density decreased over time, while another found that territory densities were similar between sites planted with oak saplings and unplanted sites (360). Two site comparison studies found that mammal species richness in restored forests was similar to that in established forests (2570). One of two replicated studies found that replanted or regrowing forest supported a higher abundance of hazel dormice than did coppiced forest, while the other study found only low numbers of common brushtail possums or common ringtail possums by 7–30 years after planting (2570). Restored forest areas had higher reptile abundance than remnant forest areas, according to one replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia (3749). Two of three replicated studies found that areas of restored forest had similar abundances of snakes and six lizard species as unrestored areas (3749). One site comparison study in Brazil found that a reforested area had significantly lower bat diversity than a native forest fragment (2050). However, a replicated, controlled, site comparison study in Australia found that forests restored after mining had significantly higher or similar bat activity as unmined forests for five of seven bat species (2050). Three site comparison studies found that naturally generating or secondary forest had a different community composition of caterpillars, moths, and butterflies to replanted forest, oil palm plantations, pasture, or remnant primary forest (3936). Three replicated, site comparison studies found that secondary forest had a similar species richness of butterflies and moths to agroforestry plantations, pasture, and remnant forest (3936).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3749",
  "action_title": "Create or restore forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of creating or restoring forests on reptile populations. Three studies were in the USA, two were in Australia and one was in Mexico.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One of two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in the USA and Australia found that restored and natural riparian forest had similar reptile species richness. The other study found that restored forest areas had higher reptile species richness than remnant forest areas. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that the type of restoration had mixed effects on reptile species richness in tropical and subtropical areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Abundance (5 studies): Two of three replicated studies (including two controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Mexico found that areas of restored forest had similar abundances of snakes and six lizard species as unrestored areas. The other study found that restoring forest stands had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that areas with different restoration types had similar reptile abundance in tropical and subtropical areas. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that restored forest areas had higher reptile abundance than remnant forest areas.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2050",
  "action_title": "Restore or create forest or woodland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects of restoring forests on bat populations. One study was in Brazil and one in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study in Brazil found that a reforested area had significantly lower bat diversity than a native forest fragment.

POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled, site comparison study in Australia found that forests restored after mining had significantly higher or similar bat activity (relative abundance) as unmined forests for five of seven bat species.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2570",
  "action_title": "Restore or create forest",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects on mammals of restoring or creating forest. Two studies were in the USA and one each were in Colombia, Italy and Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (2 studies): Two site comparison studies (one replicated) in the USA and Colombia found that mammal species richness in restored forest was similar to that in established forest.

POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (2 studies): One of two replicated studies (one a site comparison) in Australia and Italy found that replanted or regrowing forest supported a higher abundance of hazel dormice than did coppiced forest. The other study found only low numbers of common brushtail possums or common ringtail possums by 7–30 years after planting.

BEHAVIOUR (1 STUDY)

Usage (1 study): A replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that restored riparian forest areas were visited more by carnivores than were remnant forests when restored areas were newly established, but not subsequently, whilst restored areas were not visited more frequently by black-tailed deer."
}

{
  "action_id": "360",
  "action_title": "Restore or create forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirteen of 15 studies from across the world found that bird communities in restored forests were similar to original forests or that species returned to restored sites, that species recovered significantly better than ats unrestored site, that species richness, diversity or abundances increased over time or that restoration techniques themselves improved over time. 
Nine of the studies found that some species did not return to restored sites, or were less common than in original forests.  One study also found that overall territory density decreased over time and another found that territory densities were similar between sites planted with oak Quercus spp. saplings and unplanted sites.
One study from the USA found that productivity of birds was similar in restored and natural forests. Another found that productivity was lower. 
A study from the USA found that fast-growing cottonwood forests less than ten years old held more territories and had higher diversity than similarly-aged oak forests."
}

{
  "action_id": "3936",
  "action_title": "Restore or create forest or woodland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of restoring or creating forest or woodland. Three studies were in the UK, two studies were in Brazil and one was in each of the USA, Cameroon, Mexico, Malaysia and Costa Rica.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Community composition (4 studies): Three site comparison studies (including two replicated studies) in Mexico, Costa Rica and Brazil found that naturally generating or secondary forest had a different community composition of caterpillars6, geometrid and arctiine moths and butterflies to replanted forest, oil palm plantations, pasture or remnant primary forest. One site comparison study in Brazil found that a 54-year-old restored forest had a higher proportion of fruit-feeding forest butterfly species than 11–22-year-old restored forests, and a similar community composition to a remnant forest.
Richness/diversity (6 studies): Three replicated, site comparison studies in Cameroon, Costa Rica and Brazil found that secondary forest had a similar species richness of butterflies and geometrid and arctiine moths to agroforestry plantations, pasture and remnant forest. Two of these studies also found that secondary forest had a greater species richness of butterflies and geometrid and arctiine moths than cropland or oil palm plantations. One of two site comparison studies (including one replicated study) in Brazil and Malaysia found that a 54-year-old restored forest had a lower species richness of fruit-feeding butterflies than 11–22-year-old restored forests. The other study found that 5–60-year-old restored forests had a greater species richness of butterflies than newly restored forests (<3-years-old), but restored forests had a lower species richness than primary forests. One site comparison study in Mexico found that a forest restored by natural regeneration had a similar diversity of caterpillars to a forest restored by planting.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (6 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies in Cameroon and Costa Rica found that secondary forest had a higher abundance of butterflies and geometrid and arctiine moths than cropland or oil palm plantations. One of these studies also found that secondary forest had a similar abundance of butterflies to coffee and cocoa agroforestry, and the other study also found that secondary forest had a lower abundance of geometrid and arctiine moths than primary forest. One site comparison study in Mexico found that a forest restored by natural regeneration had a similar abundance of caterpillars to a forest restored by planting. Two of three studies in the UK reported that where forest had been restored with coppicing, felling and ride management, the number of populations of high brown fritillary, pearl-bordered fritillary, wood white and grizzled skipper stayed the same or increased. The other study found that the number of heath fritillary colonies decreased after management.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (3 studies): Two studies (including one paired study) in the USA and the UK found that in forest restored with selective logging or coppicing, felling and ride widening orange sulphur and heath fritillary butterflies, but not pine white butterflies, flew into restored areas more than unrestored areas and occupied a greater area than before the sites were restored. One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK reported that in forest restored with coppicing, felling and ride management, high brown fritillary presence was the same or higher than before restoration, and after restoration the butterflies were more likely to be present at sites with high brash and bracken litter coverage."
}

query: To aid the establishment of newly planted trees in a restoration project, what actions are available to protect them from competition and other threats?
relevant_summary: To protect newly planted trees, one replicated, controlled study in Panama found that shading increased the survival rate of planted native tree seedlings [1269]. Additionally, six of seven studies, including five replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Canada and Sweden, found that ground preparation treatments increased the survival and growth rate of planted trees [1263].

Additionally, six of seven studies, including five replicated, randomized, controlled studies in Canada and Sweden, found that ground preparation treatments increased the survival and growth rate of planted trees [1263].","action_ids":["1269","1263"],"query":"To aid the establishment of newly planted trees in a restoration project, what actions are available to protect them from competition and other threats?"}

query: In the USA, what are the documented effects of different post-harvesting management techniques on young trees and understory vegetation?
relevant_summary:
A review of studies in the USA and other countries on the effects of post-harvesting management techniques on young trees and understory vegetation reveals varied outcomes. For instance, the removal of woody debris after a timber harvest has been found to have mixed effects, with one study indicating an increase in understory vegetation cover, while three others reported no effect or mixed results (1213). Similarly, the impact on understory vegetation species richness and diversity was either non-existent or mixed in four studies, and two studies showed no effect on the cover and species diversity of trees (1213). Regarding young trees, one study noted an increase in density after debris removal, another a decrease, and three studies found either mixed effects or no effect on density (1213).

Shelterwood harvesting, on the other hand, has been shown to be more consistently beneficial. Six out of seven studies, which included research from the USA, found that this technique increased the abundance, species richness, and diversity of understory plants, as well as the growth and survival rate of young trees. However, one study contradicted these findings, reporting a decrease in plant species richness and abundance, and another found no effect on tree abundance (1223).

Group-selection harvesting has also yielded mixed results. Four of eight studies, including one in the USA, found that it increased the cover and diversity of understory plants and the density of young trees. Conversely, two studies found a decrease in understory species richness and biomass, while another two studies found no effect on understory species richness and diversity, and two more found no effect on the density and growth-rate of young trees (1224).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of post-harvesting management techniques on young trees and understory vegetation in the USA"}

query: As an alternative to using herbicides, what other methods can be used to control vegetation competition for seedlings and young trees?
relevant_summary:
Mechanically removing understory vegetation after tree planting has been studied as an alternative to herbicides [1256]. Five studies in multiple countries found no effect of this practice on seedling emergence, survival, growth rate, or frost damage, though one study did find that removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass [1256]. Another study showed that removing sheep laurel shrubs specifically, increased the growth rate and height of black spruce seedlings [1256].

Other methods include clearing vegetation before planting, which had no significant effect on seedling height or diameter in some studies [3334]. However, one study found that baldcypress seedlings were taller when planted amongst cut woody vegetation [3334]. The removal of reed canarygrass before planting was found to often increase the survival rate of tree and shrub seedlings [3334]. In one study, there were more seedlings in plots that had been cleared of vegetation before sowing seeds [3334].

Disturbing the soil before seeding or planting is another alternative. Four out of five studies found that this action increased plant emergence [3413]. One study found that disturbing the soil before planting forb seedlings had no effect on their growth, but another found that it increased the cover of forb species [3413]. One study also found that disturbing soil before sowing seeds increased seedling survival [3413].

Planting or seeding under established vegetation has also been considered, with one study showing mixed effects on blackbrush seedling emergence [1714].

Finally, the addition of mulch has been studied. One study in Canada found that adding mulch before sowing seeds increased the number of seedlings in most cases [3425]. However, its effects on growth and cover are varied, with one study finding it increased the cover of target plant species, while another found it reduced the cover of planted species [3425]. A different study found that adding mulch did not alter the growth of seven different plant species [3425].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"vegetation control competition for seedlings and young trees without herbicides"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3334",
  "action_title": "Remove vegetation that could compete with planted trees/shrubs: freshwater wetlands",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects, on trees/shrubs planted in freshwater wetlands, of removing competing plants. Four studies were in the USA. Two of these took place in the same swamp, but with different experimental set-ups. One study was in Australia.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE
 
VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (3 studies): Three replicated, controlled studies (two also randomized, two also paired) in a wet meadow in Australia and a degraded swamp in the USA found that clearing vegetation before planting tree/shrub seedlings typically had no clear or significant effect on their height, after 1–4 growing seasons. However, one of the studies in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings were taller, after three growing seasons, when planted amongst cut woody vegetation than below an uncleared canopy.
Diameter/perimeter/area (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a wet meadow in Australia found that clearing vegetation, before planting tree/shrub seedlings, typically had no significant effect on the diameter of these seedlings nine months later.

OTHER

Germination/emergence (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a wet meadow in Australia found that there were more seedlings in plots that had been cleared of vegetation before sowing tree/shrub seeds, than in plots that had not been cleared before sowing. Seedlings were counted two months after sowing.
Survival (4 studies): Three replicated, controlled studies (two also randomized, two also paired) in a wet meadow in Australia and a degraded swamp in the USA found that clearing vegetation before planting tree/shrub seedlings typically had no clear or significant effect on their survival, after 1–4 growing seasons. However, one of the studies in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings had a lower survival rate, after three growing seasons, when planted amongst cut woody vegetation than below an uncleared canopy. One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in degraded swamps in the USA found that removing reed canarygrass Phalaris arundinacea before planting tree/shrub seedlings never significantly reduced their survival rate over 1–2 growing seasons, and often increased it.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings planted into a marsh grew more in diameter, but less in height, when planted into plots cleared of vines than when planted into uncleared plots."
}

{
  "action_id": "3413",
  "action_title": "Disturb soil before seeding/planting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Seven studies examined the effects of disturbing soil before seeding/planting on grassland vegetation. Five studies were in Europe and one study was in each of the USA and China.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY (3 STUDIES)

Overall richness/diversity (2 studies): One of two replicated, controlled studies in the UK and Germany found that disturbing soil before sowing seeds increased plant and seedling species richness. The other study found no change in plant species richness or diversity.
Grass richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that rotovating soil before sowing seeds increased grass species richness in most cases compared to harrowing before sowing.
Forb richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the UK found that rotovating soil before sowing seeds increased forb species richness in most cases compared to harrowing before sowing.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE (2 STUDIES)

Overall abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the UK found that disturbing soil before sowing seeds did not alter total plant biomass.
Forb abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that disturbing soil before sowing forb seeds increased the cover of forb species.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (5 STUDIES) 

Germination/Emergence (5 studies): Four of five replicated, controlled studies (three of which were randomized and paired) in the USA, Germany, China and Spain found that disturbing soil before sowing seeds increased plant emergence in most cases compared to sowing alone. The other study found no change in seed germination.
Survival (2 studies): One of two replicated, controlled studies (one of which was randomized and paired) in China and Spain found that disturbing soil before sowing seeds increased the survival of seedlings. The other study found that ploughing to disturb soil followed by planting did not alter the survival of planted species.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that disturbing soil before planting forb seedlings had no effect on seedling growth."
}

{
  "action_id": "3425",
  "action_title": "Add mulch before or after seeding/planting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies examined the effects of adding mulch before or after seeding/planting on grassland vegetation. Two studies were in Canada, two were in the USA, and one study was in each of the UK and Germany.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY (1 STUDY)

Characteristic plant richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in Germany found that adding mulch before sowing seeds did not alter the species richness of target plants.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE (4 STUDIES)

Overall abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in Canada found that adding mulch before sowing seeds did not increase plant cover.
Characteristic plant abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in Germany found that adding mulch before sowing seeds increased the cover of target plant species.
Sown/planted species abundance (2 studies): One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the USA and UK found that adding mulch before sowing seeds did not alter the density of six sown plant species in most cases. The other study found that adding mulch before planting seedlings reduced the cover of planted species.
Individual species abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the UK found that adding mulch before planting seedlings did not alter the cover of common knapweed.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE (0 STUDIES)
OTHER (2 STUDIES) 

Germination/Emergence (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in Canada found that adding mulch before sowing seeds increased the number of seedlings in most cases.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that adding mulch after planting native prairie plants did not alter the growth of any of seven plant species."
}

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of different forest management interventions studied in Australia?
relevant_summary:
In Australia, thinning trees in forests and woodlands has been found to have varying effects on bat populations. One study noted that a forest thinned up to 20 years prior had greater bat diversity than an unthinned forest (991). Other studies found that overall bat activity was higher in thinned forests compared to unthinned ones, particularly in forests thinned up to eight years prior or more than 20 years prior (991). However, thinning was found to increase the activity of some bat species but not others (991). One study recorded the same bat species in both thinned and unthinned forests, with the exception of the chocolate wattled bat, which was not found in areas with unthinned regrowth (991).

Forest creation and restoration have shown mixed results for reptile populations. In one Australian study, restored forest areas were found to have a higher reptile species richness and abundance than remnant forest areas (3749). Conversely, another study in Australia reported that the type of restoration had varied effects on reptile species richness in tropical and subtropical regions, and that different restoration types resulted in similar reptile abundance (3749). A separate study found that restored and natural riparian forests shared a similar level of reptile species richness (3749).

The retention of wildlife corridors in logged areas has been shown to be beneficial for certain species. A study in Australia found that corridors of trees that were retained after harvesting provided support for seven different species of arboreal marsupials (2651).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "991",
  "action_title": "Thin trees within forest and woodland",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects of thinning trees within forest and woodland on bat populations. Six studies were in the USA, four were in Australia and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (2 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in Australia recorded the same bat species in thinned and unthinned forest, except for the chocolate wattled bat, which was not recorded in forests with unthinned regrowth. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that forest thinned up to 20 years previously had higher bat diversity than unthinned forest, but sites thinned more than 20 years previously did not differ.

POPULATION RESPONSE (11 STUDIES)

Abundance (11 studies): Five of six replicated, site comparison studies (including two paired sites studies and one controlled study) in the USA and Australia found higher overall bat activity (relative abundance) in thinned or thinned and burned forest than unthinned forest. The other study found similar overall bat activity in thinned and unthinned stands. One replicated, randomized, site comparison study in the USA found higher overall bat activity for three of four types of thinning and burning treatments. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that forest thinned up to eight years previously or more than 20 years previously had higher bat activity than unthinned forest, but sites thinned 8–20 years previously did not differ. Three replicated, controlled studies (including one site comparison and one before-and-after study) in Canada and Australia found that thinning increased the activity of some bat species but not others.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "3749",
  "action_title": "Create or restore forests",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies evaluated the effects of creating or restoring forests on reptile populations. Three studies were in the USA, two were in Australia and one was in Mexico.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (3 studies): One of two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in the USA and Australia found that restored and natural riparian forest had similar reptile species richness. The other study found that restored forest areas had higher reptile species richness than remnant forest areas. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that the type of restoration had mixed effects on reptile species richness in tropical and subtropical areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Abundance (5 studies): Two of three replicated studies (including two controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Mexico found that areas of restored forest had similar abundances of snakes and six lizard species as unrestored areas. The other study found that restoring forest stands had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that areas with different restoration types had similar reptile abundance in tropical and subtropical areas. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Australia found that restored forest areas had higher reptile abundance than remnant forest areas.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2651",
  "action_title": "Retain wildlife corridors in logged areas",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects on mammals of retaining wildlife corridors in logged areas. One study was in Australia and one was in Canada.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Use (2 studies): A replicated study in Australia found that corridors of trees, retained after harvesting, supported seven species of arboreal marsupial. A replicated, controlled study in Canada found that lines of woody debris through clearcut areas that were connected to adjacent forest were not used more by red-backed voles than were isolated lines of woody debris."
}

query: How do mechanical removal and herbicide application compare in their effectiveness for controlling understory vegetation after tree planting?
relevant_summary:
Five studies in Canada, the USA, France, Panama, and Sweden found no effect of controlling understory vegetation on the emergence, survival, growth rate or frost damage in planted seedlings (1256). However, one study found that removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass (1256). Another replicated, controlled study in Canada found that the removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased the growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings (1256).

Two studies in Portugal and France found that vegetation removal along with mechanical disturbance of the soil increased the cover and diversity of understory plants (1274). One of these studies also found it decreased understory shrub cover (1274). A separate study in France found that this combination of methods increased the density of young trees (1274).

Three studies in the USA found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (778). One study in Canada found that following logging, American toad abundance was similar and wood frogs were lower in stands with herbicide treatment and planting compared to stands left to regenerate naturally (778).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effectiveness of mechanical removal and herbicide application for controlling understory vegetation after tree planting"}

query: What are the observed effects of adding soil amendments or ground coverings, such as organic matter, lime, or straw, after tree planting?
relevant_summary:
A study in a created wetland in the USA found that adding a large amount of compost after planting tree seedlings resulted in a plant community characteristic of drier conditions, with lower plant species richness and diversity three years later, compared to unamended plots (3310). However, the same study found that birch saplings were larger in plots with large amounts of compost (3310).

A study in the USA found that covering the ground with mulch after planting increased total plant cover (1240). Another study in the Czech Republic found that covering the ground with straw after tree planting increased the growth rate of planted trees and shrubs, while bark or fleece did not have the same effect (1266).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of adding soil amendments or ground coverings after tree planting"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3310",
  "action_title": "Add below-ground organic matter before/after planting trees/shrubs: freshwater wetlands",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of adding below-ground organic matter to freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. The study was in the USA.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a created wetland in the USA found that amongst plots planted with tree seedlings, those amended with large amounts compost contained a plant community characteristic of drier conditions, three years later, than the community in unamended plots. The lowest compost dose had no significant effect on this outcome.
Overall richness/diversity (1 study): The same study found that amongst plots planted with tree seedlings, those amended with a large amount of compost had lower plant species richness and diversity, three years later, than unamended plots. Lower compost doses had no significant effect on either outcome.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Overall abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a created wetland in the USA found that amongst plots planted with tree seedlings, those amended with compost supported a similar overall vegetation biomass, three years later, to unamended plots.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Individual plant size (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a created wetland in the USA found that birch Betula saplings were larger, three years after planting seedlings, in plots amended with large amounts of compost than in unamended plots."
}

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"effects of soil amendments after tree planting"}
{"query_string":"effects of ground coverings after tree planting"}

query: What is the evidence on the long-term effectiveness of using tree guards to protect planted trees?
relevant_summary: One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that using light but not dark coloured plastic tree shelters increased the survival rate of planted tree seedlings (1268). One replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 but not 44 months (1268). One replicated, paired, controlled study in Australia reported that planted seedlings had a much higher survival rate over one year in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots (3330). In contrast, two replicated, paired, controlled studies in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings but sometimes had no clear or significant effect (3330). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that planted seedlings grew more over one growing season when protected with plastic guards (3330). However, another study in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years (3330).

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"long-term effectiveness of using tree guards to protect planted trees"}

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "3330",
  "action_title": "Use fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, those also fenced to exclude deer contained taller tree seedlings, after three years, than those left unfenced. One replicated, paired, controlled study in created freshwater wetlands in the USA found that the average height of white cedar Thuja occidentalis saplings typically increased by a similar amount, between two and five years after planting, in plots fenced to exclude deer and plots left unfenced.

OTHER

Survival (3 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in floodplain swamps in Australia reported that planted swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora seedlings had a much higher survival rate, over one year, in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings but sometimes had no clear or significant effect. This depended on factors such as the season of planting, seedling elevation, and site.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in a nutria-invaded wetland in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings grew more, over one growing season, when protected than when left unprotected. Plastic guards increased height and diameter growth rates. Sticky, insect-repellent oil increased the growth rate for height, but not diameter."
}
